custom_fields.key_topics: The major goal of this course is to examine the relations between the brain and behavior so that we can arrive at a better understanding of how complex cognitive behavior is mediated by the underlying neural substrate. The emphasis of the course is on the detailed behavior of patients with brain damage and how this correlates to behavioral changes, whereby we make inferences about the underlying functional neuroanatomy. This course covers disordered cognition related to our sensory and motor systems as well as to higher levels of cognitions such as memory, language, spatial organization and object recognition.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: 85211 is a prerequisite and 85219 is highly recommended
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Generally, course assessment is conducted via exams, student presentations on a topic of interest and written papers synthesizing case studies and research papers.
custom_fields.goals: This course will further advance student understanding of the dynamics of how functional neuroanatomy is related to complex behaviors.
custom_fields.relevance: This course counts towards the minors in psychology, cognitive neuroscience and neuroscience.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Research papers are provided that are relevant to the topics discussed, there is also a textbook that we refer to, paper, documentary and movie based case studies.

long_desc: This course will review what has been learned of the neural bases of cognition through studies of braindamaged patients as well as newer techniques such as brain stimulation mapping, regional metabolic and blood flow imaging, and attempt to relate these clinical and physiological data to theories of the mind cast in informationprocessing terms. The course will be organized into units corresponding to the traditionallydefined subfields of cognitive psychology such as perception, memory and language. In each area, we will ask To what extent do the neurological phenomena make contact with the available cognitive theories When they do, what are their implications for these theories i.e., Can we confirm or disconfirm particular cognitive theories using neurological data When they do not, what does this tell us about the parses of the mind imposed by the theories and methodologies of cognitive psychology and neuropsychology

prereqs.text: (85-219 at least D) or (85-211 at least D)

name: Cognitive Neuropsychology
